user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.2 is: Functions shall not call themselves, either directly or indirectly.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of iov_max_init_:
```c
static void
iov_max_init_ (void)
{
  long res = sysconf (_SC_IOV_MAX);
  if (res >= 0)
    mhd_iov_max_ = (unsigned long) res;
  else
  {
#if defined(IOV_MAX)
    mhd_iov_max_ = IOV_MAX;
#else  /* ! IOV_MAX */
    mhd_iov_max_ = 8; /* Should be the safe limit */
#endif /* ! IOV_MAX */
  }
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function iov_max_init_:
void
MHD_send_init_static_vars_ (void)
{
#ifdef HAVE_FREEBSD_SENDFILE
  /* FreeBSD 11 and later allow to specify read-ahead size
   * and handles SF_NODISKIO differently.
   * SF_FLAGS defined only on FreeBSD 11 and later. */
#ifdef SF_FLAGS
  freebsd_sendfile_init_ ();
#endif /* SF_FLAGS */
#endif /* HAVE_FREEBSD_SENDFILE */
#if defined(HAVE_SYSCONF) && defined(_SC_IOV_MAX)
  iov_max_init_ ();
#endif /* HAVE_SYSCONF && _SC_IOV_MAX */
}
...
void
MHD_init (void)
{
#if defined(MHD_WINSOCK_SOCKETS)
  WSADATA wsd;
#endif /* MHD_WINSOCK_SOCKETS */

  MHD_set_panic_func (NULL, NULL);

#if defined(MHD_WINSOCK_SOCKETS)
  if (0 != WSAStartup (MAKEWORD (2, 2), &wsd))
    MHD_PANIC (_ ("Failed to initialize winsock.\n"));
  if ((2 != LOBYTE (wsd.wVersion)) && (2 != HIBYTE (wsd.wVersion)))
    MHD_PANIC (_ ("Winsock version 2.2 is not available.\n"));
#endif /* MHD_WINSOCK_SOCKETS */
#ifdef HTTPS_SUPPORT
#ifdef MHD_HTTPS_REQUIRE_GCRYPT
#if GCRYPT_VERSION_NUMBER < 0x010600
#if GNUTLS_VERSION_NUMBER <= 0x020b00
#if defined(MHD_USE_POSIX_THREADS)
  if (0 != gcry_control (GCRYCTL_SET_THREAD_CBS,
                         &gcry_threads_pthread))
    MHD_PANIC (_ ("Failed to initialise multithreading in libgcrypt.\n"));
#elif defined(MHD_W32_MUTEX_)
  if (0 != gcry_control (GCRYCTL_SET_THREAD_CBS,
                         &gcry_threads_w32))
    MHD_PANIC (_ ("Failed to initialise multithreading in libgcrypt.\n"));
#endif /* defined(MHD_W32_MUTEX_) */
#endif /* GNUTLS_VERSION_NUMBER <= 0x020b00 */
  gcry_check_version (NULL);
#else
  if (NULL == gcry_check_version ("1.6.0"))
    MHD_PANIC (_ ("libgcrypt is too old. MHD was compiled for " \
                  "libgcrypt 1.6.0 or newer.\n"));
#endif
#endif /* MHD_HTTPS_REQUIRE_GCRYPT */
  gnutls_global_init ();
#endif /* HTTPS_SUPPORT */
  MHD_monotonic_sec_counter_init ();
  MHD_send_init_static_vars_ ();
  MHD_init_mem_pools_ ();
  /* Check whether sizes were correctly detected by configure */
#ifdef _DEBUG
  if (1)
  {
    struct timeval tv;
    mhd_assert (sizeof(tv.tv_sec) == SIZEOF_STRUCT_TIMEVAL_TV_SEC);
  }
#endif /* _DEBUG */
  mhd_assert (sizeof(uint64_t) == SIZEOF_UINT64_T);
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
I included the three function bodies that form the initialization call chain in the provided code: iov_max_init_, MHD_send_init_static_vars_, and MHD_init. These are the obvious places to inspect for potential direct or indirect recursion because they contain calls to other (possibly user-defined) functions which might, in other translation units, call back and form a cycle.

Other fragments in the provided snippets do not need to be investigated with respect to MISRA C:17.2 for these reasons:
- The internal statements inside iov_max_init_ are simple library/system calls (sysconf) and constant assignments; there is no function call to itself or to other local functions beyond sysconf (a standard library function) and trivial macro-based fallbacks. These cannot introduce recursion by themselves.
- The conditional/compile-time macro blocks, assertions, and type/size checks (e.g. mhd_assert, sizeof checks) do not contain function calls that could create recursive call chains within this module.
- Calls to well-known external library initialization functions (WSAStartup, gnutls_global_init, gcry_check_version, gcry_control, freebsd_sendfile_init_ where present) are external; while they are included in the suspicious fragments above if they appear inside the inspected functions, there is no evidence in the supplied code that any of these library functions call back into the listed init functions. If desired, investigators should check the definitions of the external/third-party functions (freebsd_sendfile_init_, gnutls_*, gcry_*, WSAStartup, etc.) to ensure they do not call back into MHD_init, MHD_send_init_static_vars_, or iov_max_init_.

No other lines in the supplied code present any plausible path for direct or indirect self-calls beyond the three included fragments, so they are not reported for further MISRA C:17.2 investigation.
